statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Montana State 62, Montana 60
article.story: MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) -- It wasn't how they drew it up, but Montana State coach Mick Durham was happy with the outcome of his team's final play -- a 3-pointer by Ja'Ron Jefferson with 0.6 seconds left to give the Bobcats a 62-60 victory over Montana Saturday night. "It's not what we diagrammed, but it is in the corner we put it in," said Durham, whose team opened its Big Sky Conference slate with three straight road victories, after going winless on the road in the preseason. Jefferson finished with 25 points, including 4-of-5 from 3-point range and made all seven of his free throws while getting five steals and holding Montana's leading scorer Kevin Criswell to 2-of-9 shooting and nine points. Montana (7-9, 1-2) took a 60-55 lead on a layup by Matt Martin with 2:31 remaining before Montana State (8-8) closed the game with a 7-0 run. Baskets by Jefferson and Marvin Moss pulled MSU within 60-59 with 1:25 remaining. Montana had a turnover and MSU missed a shot, which was rebounded by John Seyfert. But Criswell shot an airball for Montana and MSU called a timeout to set up a final play. "We were planning to go low to Marvin, but Kevin Criswell was cheating -- helping out -- so I kicked it to Ja'Ron and he made a big shot," Branden Miller said. Jefferson said: "Time was running out, so I just let it fly." Montana coach Larry Krystkowiak called it a "big time shot. It was awesome. It's tough to be on the losing end of it, but that's what it's all about. You can't say we were bad defensively. That's the deal when a two will beat you, you assume that's what's going to happen. If a guy hits a big 3 fading out of bounds, we can live with it," he said. Moss finished with 13 points and eight rebounds for MSU while Miller added 11 points and six assists. Seyfert led Montana with 14 points and nine rebounds, while Martin had 13 points and five assists and Matt Dlouhy had 12 points. The Bobcats jumped out to an early 20-7 lead on three free throws by Jefferson with 13:01 remaining. Montana answered with a 18-2 run, including two 3-pointers by Martin, to take a 25-22 lead with 3:44 remaining. MSU led 32-31 at halftime and built a 42-35 lead on a 3-pointer by Moss with 17:16 to play. The score was tied five times over the remainder of the game, the last time at 55-all with 3:33 left. Montana outrebounded Montana State 42-30 and outshot the Bobcats 42 percent to 38 percent. "That's probably why it was so close, because of the rebounding," Moss said. "Well, we had 10 3's," Durham pointed out. "When you come into this building and get 10 3's and only turn it over seven times, that helps."
